Title: Telemedicine in Minority and Socioeconomically Disadvantaged Communities Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic
Main Findings: Cultural views influence attitudes; minorities chose Telehealth due to linguistic/economic barriers to in-person care.

Title: Telehealth Use for Enhancing the Health of Rural Older Adults: A Systematic Mixed Studies Review
Main Findings: Telehealth is a cost-efficient method for rural healthcare compared to traditional consultations.

Title: Children with uncontrolled asthma from economically disadvantaged neighborhoods...
Main Findings: 60-70% of children with asthma miss appointments due to transport; Telehealth enables home-based treatment.

Title: Health Inequalities in the Use of Telehealth in the United States in the Lens of COVID-19
Main Findings: Majority were mental health seekers; rural use lower than urban; 845% surge in outpatient Telehealth during COVID.

Title: Telehealth: Seven Strategies To Successfully Implement Disruptive Technology
Main Findings: 7 success strategies: patient/provider expectations, revenue models, deconstructing traditional care, etc.

Title: The “Telehealth Divide”—Who Are the Underserved, and What Care Is Improved?
Main Findings: Examines racial disparities in wellness, visits, drug safety, and medical abortion post-pandemic.

Title: Using Telehealth Technologies to Improve Oral Health for Vulnerable...
Main Findings: Emerging evidence that telehealth enhances oral health delivery for vulnerable/underserved populations.

Title: Understanding the Intention to Use Telehealth Services in Underserved Hispanic Border Communities
Main Findings: Measured attitudes at Texas-Mexico border; Telehealth literacy fosters positive feelings toward the service.

Title: Telehealth: Reducing or increasing cancer care disparities?
Main Findings: Shows disparities among historically underserved cancer patients of varying ethnicities and ages.

Title: Addressing Mental Health needs of the rural underserved
Main Findings: Mental health services effectively delivered via distance tech; requires tech accommodations for both parties.

Title: Addressing health disparities in rural communities using telehealth
Main Findings: Improves satisfaction and reduces costs; addresses geographic maldistribution of pediatric specialists.

Title: Early Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Experience With the Use of Telehealth to Address Disparities
Main Findings: Disparities reduced by patient-centered care and strong provider-patient connections.

Title: A cross-sectional survey and service evaluation of simple telehealth in primary care
Main Findings: High satisfaction; easy to use; schedule flexibility and improved hypertension education in general population.

Title: Portable Health Clinic: A Telehealthcare System for UnReached Communities
Main Findings: Successful in Bangladesh for NCDs/aging; reduces morbidity; drawback: cannot handle communicable diseases.

Title: The application of telehealth to remote and rural Australians with chronic neurological conditions
Main Findings: Rural Australians highly satisfied; 100% would recommend; beneficial for chronic conditions without re-exam.

Title: Cardiogenic shock complicating acute myocardial infarction--etiologies...
Main Findings: Smartphone-paired ECG/Echo in Zimbabwe; data sent to US specialists; identified CVD in high-risk populations.

Title: Telehealth is a Sustainable Population Health Strategy to Lower Costs...
Main Findings: Saves time/money for rural Utah patients; barriers include staffing, training, and maintenance.

Title: Telehealth delivery of the diabetes prevention program to rural communities
Main Findings: Comparable results to on-site programs in weight loss/participation for rural communities.

Title: The reported benefits of telehealth for rural Australians
Main Findings: Potential to reduce access lack in rural Australia; requires practitioner upskilling for implementation.
